Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Using the Rurutu hotspot to evaluate mantle motion and absolute plate motion models
Award.AbstractNarration: Linear tracks of submarine volcanoes (i.e., the Hawaiian-Emperor and Louisville volcanic chains) define the trace of the two longest-lived Pacific hotspots. These two hotspot tracks have long been used to model tectonic plate motion and define how the continents have moved over the face of the globe over time. It has generally been believed that hotspots, which originate deep in the mantle, are fixed and that, as the plate moves over it, the hot spot punches through the crust resulting in a linear chain of volcanoes that can be used to show the speed and direction of plate motion over 10's of millions of years. Mounting evidence now, however, indicates that hotspots may not actually be fixed with respect to the mantle or each other. To test the hypothesis of a moving hotspot reference frame, this research will define a third, long-lived, Pacific hotspot track, the Rurutu hotspot, and compare it with the Hawaiian-Emperor and Louisville chains. Twenty submarine volcanoes near the Samoa Islands in the western Pacific Ocean will be sampled and geochemical analyses of the lavas will be collected. Argon, produced from radioactive decay, will be used to determine the ages of the volcanoes. The chemisty of the lavas, especially the elemental abundances and the Sr, Ne, Pb, and Hf isotopes signatures, will be used to (1) distinguish Rurutu volcanoes from unrelated ones and (2) determine the geochemical fingerprint and evolution of the hotspot. Samples dredged from the seafloor will be described and analyzed on the ship by Laser Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy. Mapping and marine geophysical data will be collected and used to guide potential dredging targets. Broader impacts include a strong and large student training component in which three graduate students and 10 undergraduates will go to sea and be intimately involved in the project. This will help build a more diverse scientific workforce by recruiting students from a Hispanic Serving Institution in Texas and training them in state-of-the-art geochemical analysis and data interpretation. This research will foster inter-institutional collaboration between three institutions and will support two early career investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mantle plumes are thought to rise buoyantly from the deep mantle. A common hypothesis is that they transport ancient subducted oceanic crust to the shallow mantle where the crustally-derived materials melt and give rise to ocean island volcanism erupted at hotspots. The Cook Austral volcanic chain, located in the south Pacific, has been proposed to result from three distinct hotspots. Lavas erupted at two of the three hotspot tracks emerging from the Cook-Austral volcanic chain, anchored at Macdonald and Arago seamounts, respectively, are characterized by radiogenic Pb-isotopic compositions (referred to as a ‘HIMU’ component). The third hotspot track, anchored to Rarotonga Island, hosts geochemically-enriched signatures that are characteristic of an enriched mantle 1 (EM1) component. All three hotspots have been proposed to be long-lived (100 million years) and geochemically continuous. The three Cook-Austral hotspots are predicted to exhibit bends in the hotspot tracks, like the Hawaii-Emperor bend (HEB), which was generated at ~47 Ma. A plate reconstruction predicts the location of the HEB-like bend of the second hotspot in the Cook-Austral chain—the Rurutu hotspot—and the seamounts and atolls of the Tuvalu island chain coincide with the predicted portion of the Rurutu hotspot the lies before then bend. If lavas from Tuvalu islands were formed at the Rurutu hotspot, they are predicted to have ages between ~47 and ~60 Ma, and they are predicted to have HIMU geochemical signatures similar to those erupted in the Cook-Austral volcanic chain. A primary goal of this proposal was to prospect for HIMU geochemical signatures in the Tuvalu islands and determine whether these ancient volcanoes have ages consistent with being the portion of the Rurutu hotspot that was formed prior to the HEB-like bend in the hotspot.

In order to test these hypotheses, we carried out a 31-day dredging expedition on the R/V Roger Revelle to collect and subsequently analyze samples from the Tuvalu atolls and seamounts. Most of the dredge targets in the Tuvalu islands and seamounts were successful, and we now have age-dates and geochemical data on this critical portion of the Rurutu hotspot. The ages show that the Tuvalu islands and seamounts are age progressive and support the hypothesis that the Tuvalu islands and seamounts define an older portion of the Rurutu hotspot track that was formed prior to the HEB-like bend in the Pacific. The geochemistry of the lavas from the Tuvalus exhibit a HIMU signature that support the hypothesis that the Tuvalus are geochemically related to the Rurutu hotspot.  In summary, the combination of age-dates and geochemistry provide powerful support for the hypothesis that the Tuvalu islands and seamounts define an older portion of the Rurutu hotspot, as the Rurutu hotspot exhibits an age-progression and an HEB-like bend at ~47 Ma.

Two additional important, unanticipated discoveries were made during and shortly after the cruise. First, basaltic glass was found on many of the seamounts dredged in the Tuvalu atolls. Preliminary geochemical results show that these glasses are HIMU in composition. This is a fantastic discovery, as the community has been without a deeply-dredged HIMU glass. Our discovery marks the first report of a deeply-dredged HIMU glass, which allowed us to measure, for the first time, relatively undegassed volatile budgets of HIMU lavas. The glasses have been measured for volatile, major and trace element concentrations and Pb-isotopic ratios. The data indicate that the HIMU mantle reservoir is more dehydrated that previous suggested. If the HIMU reservoir formed by subducting ancient oceanic crust, then data from the new glasses have implications for volatile transport from subduction zones to hotspots.
